title: 109_hr2737
content: The Act may be cited as the "Office of Correctional Public Health Act of 2005". The Congress finds that approximately 2.1 million people are incarcerated in the United States, with a 28 percent increase in inmates between 1995 and 2000. Offender populations in jails have a high turnover rate, and at least 95 percent of those incarcerated will be released. These populations also have a higher rate of chronic and communicable diseases upon entry, including asthma, diabetes, hepatitis, HIV/AIDS, and tuberculosis. Additionally, the prevalence of mental illness in correctional facilities is on the rise, with estimates of 14 to 20 percent of jail inmates in 1996 experiencing some form of anxiety. In 1996, a high percentage of jail inmates had anxiety disorders, while between 22 and 30 percent of State prison inmates had the same issue. The prevalence of AIDS among inmates was 3.5 times higher than in the general population. An estimated 98,500 to 145,500 HIV-positive inmates were released from prisons and jails in 1996. Additionally, between 12 and 15 percent of individuals with chronic hepatitis B infection in the US spent time in a correctional facility that year. Between 1.3 and 1.4 million inmates released in 1996 were infected with hepatitis C, with a prevalence 9 to 10 times higher than in the general population. In the United States, a significant percentage of individuals with hepatitis C virus are former prisoners or have a history of incarceration. Substance abuse is prevalent among incoming prisoners, with a high percentage of state and federal prisoners being alcohol-involved or drug-involved offenders. The Public Health Service Act is amended to establish the Office of Correctional Public Health. The Public Health Service Act is amended to establish the Office of Correctional Public Health within the Office of Public Health and Science. The Office is responsible for carrying out correctional health activities for individuals in penal or correctional institutions at the federal, state, or local level. Correctional health activities include disease prevention, health promotion, service delivery, research, and health professions education in various types of penal or correctional institutions. These institutions include facilities for individuals awaiting judicial or administrative proceedings, as well as minors held for violations of the law. The Secretary coordinates correctional health programs, provides support to State and local agencies, cooperates with other Federal agencies, consults with State directors, facilitates information exchange, and promotes collaboration in correctional health activities. The Secretary may provide grants to States for correctional populations to receive screenings, immunizations, and treatment for hepatitis A, B, and C, with the option for States to use the grant for various activities authorized under the program. Matching funds may be required for the program costs. The Secretary may grant funds to States for correctional populations to receive screenings, immunizations, and treatment for hepatitis A, B, and C. States must provide non-Federal contributions of at least 20% of the costs, which can be in cash or in kind, excluding Federal assistance. The Secretary may make grants for correctional health activities, with States required to contribute at least 20% of the costs. Activities can include services at penal or correctional institutions not for imprisonment. An annual report on correctional health activities must be submitted to Congress. Authorization of appropriations for correctional health programs under the Office of Correctional Public Health Act of 2005, with specific funding allocated for hepatitis-related grants. The Office of Correctional Public Health Act of 2005 authorized appropriations of $15,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2006 to 2008, and $5,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2009 to 2010.
